results.definition: a specific size and style of type within a type family
an enveloping structure or covering enclosing an animal or plant organ or part
the enclosing frame around a door or window opening
a person of a specified kind (usually with many eccentricities)
(printing) the receptacle in which a compositor has his type, which is divided into compartments for the different letters, spaces, or numbers
examples: for English, a compositor will ordinarily have two such cases, the upper case containing the capitals and the lower case containing the small letters

results.definition: the quantity contained in a case
the housing or outer covering of something
examples: the clock has a walnut case

results.definition: bed linen consisting of a cover for a pillow
examples: the burglar carried his loot in a pillowcase

results.definition: a special set of circumstances
examples: it may rain in which case the picnic will be canceled

results.definition: an occurrence of something
examples: it was a case of bad judgment

results.definition: enclose in, or as if in, a case
examples: my feet were encased in mud

results.definition: nouns or pronouns or adjectives (often marked by inflection) related in some way to other words in a sentence
a comprehensive term for any proceeding in a court of law whereby an individual seeks a legal remedy
a person who is subjected to experimental or other observational procedures; someone who is an object of investigation
examples: the cases that we studied were drawn from two different communities

results.definition: a glass container used to store and display items in a shop or museum or home
a person requiring professional services
examples: a typical case was the suburban housewife described by a marriage counselor

results.definition: a portable container for carrying several objects
examples: the musicians left their instrument cases backstage

results.definition: a problem requiring investigation
examples: Perry Mason solved the case of the missing heir

results.definition: a specific state of mind that is temporary
a statement of facts and reasons used to support an argument
look over, usually with the intention to rob
the actual state of things
